author: Luis Garcia
title: Explosive Lawsuit Unveils F1's Financial Secrets in NASCAR Battle for Monopoly Control
text:
In a bold move that is shaking the foundations of the racing world, 23XI Racing and Front Row Motorsports are on a mission to unveil the hidden truths behind F1â€™s finances as part of their groundbreaking lawsuit against NASCAR. The teams are leaving no stone unturned, filing court motions and subpoenas to demand transparency and justice in a legal battle that could change the landscape of motorsports forever.
With a recent motion filed in the US District Court of Colorado, 23XI Racing and Front Row Motorsports are aiming to compel Liberty Media, the owner of Formula 1, to disclose crucial financial documents that could potentially expose NASCARâ€™s inner workings. By delving into F1â€™s financial details, the teams hope to gather evidence to challenge the France familyâ€™s stronghold over NASCAR, accusing them of operating the sport as an illegal monopoly and violating antitrust laws.
The â€˜yardstick methodâ€™ is being employed by the teams, a legal strategy to showcase economic damages and unfair practices within the sport. They are seeking specific revenue numbers from F1, including intricate details on broadcasting, sponsorship, ticket sales, merchandise, and various other revenue streams. The ultimate goal is to shed light on the financial intricacies of the sport and prove their case against NASCAR.
Not stopping there, the teams are also targeting the NFL, NBA, and NHL in a similar motion filed in the US District Court of New York City. This multi-front legal battle signifies a pivotal moment in the history of motorsports, with high stakes and dramatic implications for all parties involved.
23XI Racing, co-owned by basketball legend Michael Jordan and racing icon Denny Hamlin, along with Front Row Motorsports, are standing firm against what they perceive as unjust terms in NASCARâ€™s Charter Agreement. Their refusal to comply and subsequent legal action have sparked a fierce legal showdown that has been unfolding since last year, with no signs of slowing down.
As the legal drama intensifies and the battle for transparency rages on, the racing world braces for a seismic shift that could redefine the sport as we know it. Stay tuned as this high-octane legal saga unfolds, with the future of NASCAR hanging in the balance.

author: Suhauna Hussain - Los Angeles Times (TNS)
title: After a pandemic strike, nurses union must pay California's Riverside hospital millions in damages
text:
LOS ANGELES â€” The union representing nurses at Riverside Community Hospital has been ordered to pay more than $6 million to the hospital for the fallout from a 2020 strike.
The unusual financial penalty was imposed by an arbitrator who found the 10-day work stoppage during the pandemic violated the terms of the labor agreement signed by HCA Healthcare, which operates the hospital, and Service Employees International Union Local 121RN. The $6.26-million fine, the arbitrator determined, was necessary to compensate the hospital for the cost of replacing workers who walked off the job during the strike, according to a statement released Wednesday.
Nurses
walked off the job in June 2020 in an effort to force the hospital to increase staffing and improve safety as COVID-19 infections surged, the union said at the time. But hospital officials argued that because nurses also voiced complaints about shortages of personal protective equipment, the reasons for the strike were too expansive to be allowed under the collective bargaining agreement the two sides had signed.
"Our contract was clear, and the union showed reckless disregard for its members and the Riverside community by calling the strike," said Jackie Van Blaricum, president of HCA Healthcare's Far West Division, who was the hospital's chief executive during the strike. "We applaud the arbitrator's decision."
SEIU 121RN Executive Director Rosanna Mendez objected to the arbitrator's findings, saying nurses were permitted under their contract to go on strike. She called the arbitrator's decision "absurd and outrageous."
"It is absolutely shocking that an arbitrator would expect nurses to not talk about safety issues," Mendez said, adding that the union was exploring its options to contest the arbitrator's decision.
